growing.water: Moderate; tolerates some drought once established
growing.soil: Prefers well-drained, fertile soil; adapts to poor soils and fixes nitrogen

planting.spacing: Broadcast for ground cover; thin to 4-6 inches if growing in patches
planting.whenToPlant: Early spring or fall (cooler temps encourage establishment)
planting.propagation: Primarily by seed; spreads by creeping stems (especially white clover)
planting.depth: Surface sow or lightly cover (~1/8 inch)

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Mow or trim to encourage fresh growth or control spread
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: Perennial; tolerates winter well and regrows in spring

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Flowers: mid to late spring when fully open; Leaves: any time young and tender
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Pinch or snip flowers and leaves by hand or with scissors
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Dry flowers and leaves for tea or medicinal use; store in airtight container
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Edible in moderation; avoid consumption of moldy clover or large quantities (may cause bloating in livestock)
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Flowers and young leaves can be added to salads, teas, or used to make clover jelly

medicinal.Blood Purifier & Detoxifier: Red clover is traditionally used to support detoxification and as a gentle blood purifier.
medicinal.Hormonal Support: Contains phytoestrogens; used in folk remedies to ease menopausal symptoms.
medicinal.Respiratory Health: Historically used as an expectorant for coughs and bronchial conditions.
medicinal.Skin Soothing: Infusions applied topically for minor skin irritations or rashes.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Mildly sweet scent, especially when flowering; attractive to bees and pleasant in dried arrangements

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Often grazed by rabbits, deer, and livestock; not resistant

funFacts: Clover fixes atmospheric nitrogen, enriching the soil naturally.
A common symbol of good luck, especially the four-leaf clover variant.
Clover is often used as a living mulch or green manure in permaculture systems.
